540 wounded | casualties2 = 663 casualties{{cite book | author=Ludwik Czyżewski | title=Od Gór Borowskich do Zakroczymia | publisher=Wydawnictwo Ministerstwa Obrony Narodowej, Warsaw | year=1982 | isbn=83-11-06741-4|language=pl}} | campaignbox = {{Campaignbox Polish September Campaign}} }} [[File:Borowa hill monument.jpg|thumb|right|200px|Monument erected to commemorate the battle]] '''Battle of Borowa Góra''' ({{lang-pl|Bitwa pod Borową Górą}}) refers to the series of battles from 2 to 5 September 1939 that took place near the Góry Borowskie hills, south west from [[Piotrków Trybunalski]] and east of [[Bełchatów]]. The battle, fought between the [[Wehrmacht]] and the [[Polish Army]] in the vicinity of [[Łódź]], was a direct consequence of the ''[[Battle of the Border]]'', an early part of the German [[Invasion of Poland (1939)|Invasion of Poland]] The three hills (278 meters above sea level) formed an important strategic point that the German [[XVI Army Corps (Wehrmacht)|XVI Army Corps]] needed to break through in order to advance toward [[Radomsko]], Piotrków Trybunalski and Bełchatów, and further into central Poland. The area was defended by the [[Polish 2nd Legions' Infantry Regiment]] (part of the [[2nd Legions Infantry Division (Poland)|2nd Legions Infantry Division]]), under [[pułkownik|Col.]] Ludwik Czyżewski, and the 146th Infantry Regiment (part of the [[44th Infantry Division (Poland)|44th Infantry Division]]), under Col. Artur Pollak. Both Polish units belonged to [[Łódź Army]]. The invading German XVI Army Corps consisted of the [[1st Panzer Division (Wehrmacht)|1st Panzer Division]], the [[4th Panzer Division (Wehrmacht)|4th Panzer Division]], the [[14th Infantry Division (Wehrmacht)|14th Infantry Division]], and the [[31st Infantry Division (Wehrmacht)|31st Infantry Division]]. During the intense fighting, Polish casualties from the 2nd Legions' Regiment were 663 (including 16 officers and 67 NCOs).{{cite book | author=Stanisław Wyrzycki | title=2 Pułk Piechoty Legionów | publisher=Ajaks, Warsaw | year=2000| isbn=83-85621-05-9|language=pl}} == Background == General [[Wiktor Thommée]], who commanded Piotrków Operational Group of Łódź Army, ordered Colonel Czyżewski to defend a 25-kilometer line in the area of [[Rozprza]]. Polish units were supposed to hold their positions until September 4, when a Polish counterattack was planned from the [[Sulejów]] forests. Since Czyżewski did not have enough soldiers, he decided to man three main defensive positions, and to patrol the space between them. Center of Polish defence was established in the Góry Borowskie hills. Polish units began to man their positions in the night of September 2/3. Janowski's headquarters were at a public school in the village of Janów. General [[Juliusz Rómmel]], aware of German superiority, decided to reinforce Czyżewski, by sending the 301st Battalion of Light Tanks under Major Edmund Karpow, which consisted of 49 [[Vickers]] tanks.Czesław Grzelak, Henryk Stańczyk Kampania Polska 1939 roku, page 175. Oficyna Wydawnicza RYTM Warszawa, 2005. {{ISBN|83-7399-169-7}} ==The battle== First German units approached Polish positions near Rozprza on September 3, at 13:00. Two hours later the Panzers attacked the Góry Borowskie hills, and the fighting lasted for several hours, until the night. The Wehrmacht was supported by the [[Luftwaffe]], which bombed Polish positions, and as a result, some soldiers of the Polish Army abandoned their posts. In the evening of September 3, leading units of the German 1st Panzer Division captured Rozprza, to be pushed back after some time. At app. 15:00 tanks of the 4th Panzer Division attacked Góry Borowskie, but after a fierce battle with Polish 3rd Battalion of Major Żelazowski, they retreated and regrouped at night, to attack the hills from the east in the morning of September 4. On September 4 in the morning, German infantry of the 31st I.D. attacked along the road to Bełchatów. They were pushed back, but near Rozprza, where Panzer divisions were present, Polish defenders faced more danger. The 1st Panzer attacked Rozprza, and the 4th Panzer concentrated its efforts on capturing Jeżów. In the afternoon of September 4, whole Polish frontline was attacked between Góry Borowskie and Rozprza. Fighting lasted into the night, and in the morning of September 5, the Germans attacked again, with the support of the Luftwaffe. Under the circumstances Colonel Czyżewski ordered retreat towards Dłutów, opening for the Wehrmacht the road to Piotrków.Czesław Grzelak, Henryk Stańczyk Kampania Polska 1939 roku, page 176. Oficyna Wydawnicza RYTM Warszawa, 2005. {{ISBN|83-7399-169-7}} Since some Polish units were not aware of Czyżewski's order, in some spots fighting continued until morning of September 6. == See also == * [[Battle of Łódź (1939)|Battle of Łódź]] ==Notes and references== {{reflist}} {{coord|51.366667|19.383333|format=dms|display=title|type:event}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Borowa Gora}} [[Category:Battles of the Invasion of Poland]] [[Category:September 1939 events]]
